ai.summary: The Greenwich Meridian Trail is a long-distance hike that follows the Prime Meridian across the United Kingdom, covering approximately 1163.8 km. Starting near Greenwich, the route traverses a diverse tapestry of landscapes, from urban cores to rural countryside, historic towns, and coastal patches, presenting a serious challenge for experienced hikers seeking a through-hike along the line of longitude.
ai.terrain_summary: Expect a mix of terrains: city streets and riverside paths in urban sections, quiet lanes through rolling farmland, moorland and woodland in upland areas, and occasional coastal or riverside trails. Elevation varies with gentle gradients in some stretches and steeper segments in others, with seasonal weather influences adding mud and damp conditions in many parts.
ai.safety_notes: Prepare for a long through-hike with variable weather. Use a detailed map and compass or GPS, plan resupply points, and inform someone of your itinerary. Wear sturdy boots and waterproof clothing, bring layers, and carry a first aid kit, headlamp, whistle, and emergency bivvy. Stay aware of traffic on road sections, watch for slip hazards, and be mindful of weather changes, daylight hours, and potential river or coastal exposure.
recommended_gear: Sturdy hiking boots with good grip
Map and compass (with knowledge to navigate) or GPS device
Water bottles or hydration system plus water filter or purification tablets
High-energy food and snacks for multi-day sections
Lightweight tent or bivy sack (optional for wild camping areas)
First aid kit and blister care
Mobile power bank and charging cable
Plastic bags for wet gear and trash
ai.best_seasons: Late spring to early autumn (roughly April to October) when daylight is longer and temperatures are milder; winter hiking is more challenging due to short days and weather.
